dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subtitle: Amazonia 1960. A Ceremonial House in the upper reaches of the Amazon bas "ceremonial house" being a euphemism for a raised platfor covered by a thatched roof. In the distance, the sun slan low over an unending expanse of verdant jungle. A half dozen HIPPIE EXPATS sit around a low rough hewn ta Atop the table of Heaven an earthen bowl, decorated with  multi-colored scenes and fantastic creatures, is circled drinking cups. ETHAN RANKIN, 20, and VINCE GARWOOD, 19, the two American expats, wear jeans, sandals, T-shirts and long hair. Thei skin has a dull bluish color, the result of residue of a  purification bath. Trance music, constant, evolving, ripp below the surface. The expats look one to the other as the SHAMAN, an elderl mestivo, ladles a brownish brew from the bowl into the  individual cups. His assistant, DON MACITA, 36, helps him Ethan and Vince's expressions fluctuate from nervous to  expectant. Each cradles his cup in his hands as the Shaman, dispensi the "tea," starts to sing an ancient icaros, a ritual cha the melody which will accompany them on their journey. On a pre-arranged signal, each of the ceremonialists drin the brew in one sustained swallow. TIMECUT. NIGHT: the hippie expats are scattered to the fa reaches of the Ceremonial House, each barfing and shittin (off camera, hopefully) their insides out. Vince, wobbly, crawls to where Ethan lies:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan... (no answer) Rankin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weak, spacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan's countenance changes: his face becomes placid, his eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSIDE ETHAN'S MIND'S EYE: he shoots at sling-shot speed  across the jungle canopy, trailing stars and clouds to hi right and left; then, rapidly approaching from the horizo a giant iridescent speckled SERPENT zooms into view, its  jaws open. Inside we fly, whirling through the serpent like passenge on an animistic roller coaster, until, twisting and turni the light grows bright and bursts into a kaleidoscope of  color -- Subtitle: Mexico City, 2001.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rainbow of colored light comes from dozens of flashin bulbs reflecting off a disco ball. Trance music cross- dissolves into techno with a Latin beat. Below, a throbbing mass of kids gyrate and thrash. Amid the mass of sweating ecstatic Mexicanos, RUSSELL RAN 26, hops from one partner to the next. Russ' unkempt hair and club clothes can't disguise what he is: American,  intellectual, middle class -- a student on permanent fore leave. The music grows discordant, off. Russell looks around:  something seems wrong. He stops dancing, stares, anxious. Definitely wrong. He's growing paranoid. Is it the drugs? No, is it the mus an earthquake? No. He pushes his way toward the "Salida." A FRIEND, noticing the expression of Russ' face, calls to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go! Something's wrong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chill, come on, we'll go someplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've got to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ elbows his way outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, in a panic, throws clothes into a duffel bag in his hostel like residence. The walls are decorated with third world agit-prop,  psychedelic posters and Pre-Raphaelite prints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few stranded travelers; otherwise, empty rows of  geometric chairs. Russ leans over the counter of the only airline still open:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to get to Portland, Oregon,  US, on the next flight possible, the  next connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wouldn't be anything until  morning. Six o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put me on it. I have cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell pulls all the money he has out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Do you have a passport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulls it out) Right here. (explaining) Family emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subtitle: Portland. An institutionally plain classroom. HUME (HUGH) RANKIN, 3 stands before a mixed audience: male, female, older, youn mostly white. Rankin, angular, clean cut, wears a white shirt with a si tie. If he and his brother Russell could be put in boxes, would be "straight," and Russ would be "hip," although, i fact, neither can be so simply defined. In the back sits Vince Garwood, now 60, wearing professor jacket and tie. It's not a class per se, as indicated by the fact that so listeners drink coffee, some are dressed in soiled work  clothes, others business outfits. Hume speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I've been through this with each  of you individually, but now,  collectively, we have the joint  opportunity to air any concerns or  anxieties. This DMT --  dimethyltryptamine -- trial is the  first such study to be approved by  the FDA, so forgive us if we err on  the side of caution. We have chosen  DMT as the pioneer psychotropic  compound for several reasons: it  naturally occurs in the body, evident  in such states as schizophrenia and  manic depression. To the extent that  we can understand why Serotonin is  affected by DMT, we might unlock  some of the mysteries for such  disabling disorders. Second, it is  an intense drug. The visions will be  strong. Third, it's short acting.  It's in and out fast. Should anyone  have an unpleasant experience, at  least it will be over quickly. All  of you have previous experiences  with psychedelic drugs, some extensive  experience. This will be a much more  controlled environment. 1.0 mg/kg of  dimethyltryptamine will be injected  intramuscularly, not smoked as is  the usual practice. This retards the  speed at which the drug becomes  effective, but it's the only way to  be sure everyone receives the same  dosage. You've all signed the informed  consent forms, but I wanted to take  this opportunity to invite your  friends and relatives to an open  forum. If anyone has any questions,  please ask. If anyone has second  thoughts about being a trial subject,  you may withdraw your consent at any  time. Questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awkward seat-shifting. No one wants to appear unhip. T GIRLFRIEND of one of the trial participants half-raises h hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Rankin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you taken  dimetheltrimethitripo... (awkward communal  laugh) ...DMT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since 1970 dimethyltryptamine, along  with virtually every other  hallucinogen, has been a Schedule I  drug, meaning that any unauthorized  use is a crime. I do not break the  law. But yes, I have taken DMT,  inhaled and intramuscular, outside  the country and in legally approved  situations. Is it dangerous? Only if  you fear death by astonishment. (scattered laughter) Because you will be astonished. I  have zero qualms about administering  or using this substance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLDER MAN raises his hand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are those, and I'm not one of  them, who say this program is just  an excuse for recreational drug use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous laughter. The audience is predominantly and  unabashedly pro-drug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the word "recreational."  It implies something trivial. Vision- inducing plants are functional, and  have been for hundreds, maybe  thousands of years. They teach us  about ourselves. A DMT voyage, like  any trip, is instructional. You will  return knowing more about the world  around you and the world inside you. (beat) The purpose of the trial is not  recreational, it is scientific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Vince Garwood walk along the hallway leading fro the classroom. Participants small talk in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean were there any "spies,"  members of Fifth Estate? No, it was  cool. You did good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Vince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's such a delicate balance. You  want to be open and candid -- we  have nothing to hide; on the other  hand, we all know the devastating  effects too much publicity have had  on this type of research. (beat) I particularly liked the line about  not breaking the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume chuckles as Garwood stops at his office, opens the d Inside it's a rat's nest of books, papers and ethographic souvenirs. Framed pictures of Emmanuel Swedenborg, Willia Blake and Aldous Huxley hang between the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do you start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday. You going to be there for  the first trials?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten a.m. At the clinic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Again, good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nod goodbye as Garwood closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume drives his green Camry through the leafy South Park  streets surrounding the university. He slows, turns into the driveway of his 20's "California cottage" house. Portland, the Martha Stewart of American  cities, enforces zoning regulations to preserve the quain nature of its older neighborhoods. On the front steps sits Russell Rankin, unshaven, duffel at his side. It takes Hume, getting out of the car, a moment to recogn his brother:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, is that you? Russell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ gets up, sheepishly slouches over to his brother who embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, six months without a boo or a  bah, now -- it's great to see you.  What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just felt... I wanted to come home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come in. Meet Allison... (looks around) I guess she's not home yet. Come on  in. You want a beer or a soda or  anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugh pulls out his house keys as they walk up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water. I'm thirsty from the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ looks around the room: sofa, mismatched chairs, dini table stacked high with books -- furnishings familiar to  anyone who has spent an extended period in grad school. A Haitian painting depicting a voodoo ceremony hangs in the dining room. One corner of the room has been sectioned off. A wooden B in the Padmasana position sits on a covered pedestal, bef it, a meditation mat and between the mat and Buddha, ince censors and joss sticks. Hume returns from the kitchen bearing a glass of water. R gulps the water, sighs. There's something on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, brother, com'on, out with it.  What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I was in a club the other night,  well, last night, in Mexico City,  that's where I've been living, getting  into Indian culture and all that and  I got this feeling, this very strong  feeling, that something was wrong.  That someone was in danger --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a panic attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a premonition. (beat) Is Mom all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to see her. Is she all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ nods. Hugh sighs, confirms his brother's fears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There may be a reoccurrence of the  cancer. In her lungs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell emits a noise; he knew it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call. We'll drop by tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firm) Tomorrow afternoon. I've got to have  some time to prepare her. You two  didn't exactly leave on the best of  terms. (beat) You need some rest. And a shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freshly cut flowers in a vase; the boys' gift to their mo EVANGELINE RANKIN, 59, Russell and Hume's mother, cradles cup of coffee. The decor is middle-brow, but not cheesy ( chest, prints by local artists, etc.). Evangeline, a bit gaunt, exhibits the healthy glow associ with the Northwest's outdoor culture. She wears a shiny g cross. Hume and Russell, also holding cups of coffee, sit on the edges of their matching upholstered chairs. The mood is m formal than one would expect of a family "reunion."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mom, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from Kona. (off their reactions) The coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you out this morning, power- walking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, with Judy, but these days it's  more walk than power. In fact, we  turned back after fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward beat: no one wants to bring up her failing medica condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Russell) Are you planning to stay long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of days at least. We'll see  what happens. It's good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume sets his coffee down, gets up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go see a man about a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads for the bathroom. Evangeline and Russ smile; thi is an old family expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Russ) You were in Mexico City? (he nods) The American University?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it isn't a school in the formal  sense. It's a group of young scholars  with sympathetic interests --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a commune?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wouldn't use that term.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And these sympathetic interests,  what are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indigenous American cultures. Pre- Columbian societies. Tribal  organizations, tribal rites --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean peyote. You're talking about  peyote, right? (no reply) Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing to be ashamed of. What  do you think Hume does at the  University, at the clinic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her reply is sharp, censorious -- and full of denial:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a bio-chemist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does drug research.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a Ph.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ rolls his eyes. Her tone turns angry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything that has gone wrong with  this family can be traced directly  back to drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, stop. Just stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drugs have been the death of this  family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, already on tender hooks, reaches the end of his pro behavior:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder Dad left you. Jesus Christ.  Tell me, has he ever been in touch  with you in, what, twenty years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to cry. Hume, returning, overhearing Russ'  conversation, groans: he should have never left them alon Evangeline turns to Hume:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't changed. He's always looking  for trouble, he goes to jail --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, it was petty larceny --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was never in jail. He was on  probation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time I see him I see his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, fed up, stands up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. (to mother) I don't blame him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume grabs his brother by the arm and, shooting his mothe hard look, escorts Russ to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hume) She lives in worst case scenario- land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back) Mom, I'll call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge from the proper middle-class home. Hume, keep Russell moving, heads toward the Camry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I came back. What  was I thinking? It was a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reproachful) Russ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAM! They run smack into a thirtiesh GARDENER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asshole! Why don't you look were the  fuck you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume throws an apologetic look at the Gardener ("It's  nothing"), continues toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume, Russ, and ALLISON sit around the empty dinner plate sip tea, wine. Allison, 25, is the model of intelligent  hipness: attractive, long-hair tied in a ponytail, wearin loose plaid shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I was trying to teach my students  about life. I said to them, "The  only way you can be sure you are  loved for yourself and not for money  or sex, is if you are unattractive  and poor." But then I explained it's  very hard to be loved if you are  like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes love practically  impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They need to know what they're up  against.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh. Allison turns to Russ:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume's talked about you a lot, and I  have to say, I haven't been  disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Yeah, I really fucked up today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should go back, not tomorrow,  but soon, and apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard, edgy) That's one point of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison shakes a cigarette from a pack, lights up. Russ l to Hume; she explains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume doesn't approve of artificially  enhanced nicotine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One makes certain concessions for  love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Russ) You want one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. But you know, of course,  marijuana is also carcinogenic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison starts to stack the plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, let us help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ reaches over to assist his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Russell sit on the front steps sipping Chardonna Night crickets are interrupted by the sound of the occasi passing car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be honest, I'd sort of come to  the end of my interest in mescaline.  Mostly just getting stoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you were doing in that  club? When you had the panic attack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepish) Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MDMA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an interesting drug. There's  important work being done on Ecstacy  at John Hopkins, in Barcelona:  neuroendocrine effects, vasopressin  secretion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you into?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're starting a trial on DMT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The harmalines? Hoo boy. The heavy  stuff. How you get away with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause I'm a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you put up with it? All the  shit you have to deal with in this  country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's got to stay and fight the  good fight. The best labs are here,  the best scientists are here -- you  do work in this country and the  scientific community has to take it  seriously. Besides, with the internet,  everybody is connected now. You know  the organization MAPS? (Russ nods) Through MAPS now we're in constant  contact with research all around the  world: Spain, Finland, Brazil. It's  not like it used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good old Hume Rankin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mock me bro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifts glass) Excuse-moi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (click glasses) Things are going to change. It's too  important not to change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psilocybin, that's where I realized  I wanted to be, but I just wasn't...  well, I just I was scared. The big  drugs, the See God drugs, that's  what it's all about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This extraordinary imagery we all  have within us. These things,  unworldly things, that just appear.  Where do they come from? What are  they trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old dilemma. You open those doors  of perception, what happens? Do you  see this world more clearly or do  you come in contact with another  world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the inside come out or does the  Outside come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Freud/Jung dilemma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not politically correct, and  I'll deny I've said this if you repeat  it, but I believe there's a parallel  world of awareness that these plants  give us access to. It may be the way  primitive man first became aware of  the spiritual world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking) "Jesus was a plant."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (responding in kind) I deny it. I never said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, this DMT trial, you got everyone  signed up? (Hume nods) You can't fit one more in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a bunch of Portland Deadheads  signed up for this trial and you're  going to interview them silly.  Wouldn't it be better to have one  subject who has studied psychotropic  affect, who's personal history is  intimately conjoined with your own,  someone with whom you can truly  discuss the results of the trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you swing it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks) Yeah. If you don't advertise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. (beat) Tell me one thing, Professor Rankin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you, ah, offer Mileage Plus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell fills out a form under the MANAGER'S watchful eye The Manager can't help but notice Russ' overqualification

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have an Advancement Program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really, I'm between situations.  I need short term employment. I don't  want to be a burden on my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have an investment in training  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quizzical look) It's a counter position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a service-intensive  occupation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Banks, I've worked in the fast  food business. I seek only to be a  diligent employee. I understand  customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The local drug paraphernalia, radical press, vinyl oldies Heavy Metal store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ steps over to the counter, approaches an eighteen ye old head in a KORN T-SHIRT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wistelm. "Chuckie Wisdom."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, Chuckie. No, nah, I don't  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to hang here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got busted -- or maybe not, I'm  not sure. That was before my time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six weeks. (recognizing him) You're Russ Rankin, right? (Russ shrugs) I'm Joe. I came here, like before I  had this, like job -- you're heavy,  you were like a major dope dude huh? (calls to unseen  employee) Hey, this is Russ Rankin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ changes his mind about coming here:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TEENAGE FEMALE EMPLOYEE, tattooed, huge breasted under Marley shirt, walks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just looking for Chuckie Wisdom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's nothing. Groove on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find him, tell him I got some  crabs of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, with three other trial participants, walks down severe hospital corridor with Hume and two ASSISTANTS. Russ, looking at the patient rooms, the white walls, the  brutal machinery of modern medicine, turns to Hume:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they wonder why people have bad  trips?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The setting isn't what it should be,  but it's important to operate in a  clinical environment. Anyway, the  "set," the mind set, is more important  than the physical setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ and the other volunteers sit in leisure chairs in a  white-walled room. Each, sleeves rolled up, has a blood  pressure cuff and IV attached to one arm, a double-valve  blood needle to the other. EKG wires extend from under th smocks. The Assistant draws blood from each of the participants a Hume, wearing a blue button down collar shirt with a dark tie, lowers the lights on a rheostat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will, during the duration of the  trial, approximately twenty minutes,  draw blood at regular intervals as  well as check pupil diameters --  none of which will effect your  experience. If anything, it will  provide a comforting connection to  the real world of the clinic. Are  there any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No questions. The volunteers are prepared, even eager. Hu steps back to five video cameras, one trained on each of participants, checks if they are running: all red lights  glow. Hume steps away, looks as the door opens: Garwood enters darkened room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax your muscles, let the tension  flow from your bodies and: pay  attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume gives the signal: the Assistants move from one  participant to the next, opening the IV valves, letting t saline/DMT mix flow into the tubes. The Assistants withdr pick up their clipboards, sit on folding chairs, one agai each wall. EKG machines: heart rates slow. Trance music, first a faint echo, grows louder; the drug  starts to take effect: Russell's eyes slowly close as the camera goes through the eyelid, into his mydriatic (dilat eyeball. Author's Note: There are several extended trip sequences the script. Although I will sketch the rudimentary stages each trip, words are inadequate to describe a multi-layer constantly morphing hallucinogenic experience. Although t trip descriptions necessarily fall into linear, logical  patterns, the final screen images should be much more fre flowing and imagistic. A better reference would be by the computer graphic "trip" videos put out by Sony Music Vide (with titles like "Odyssey Into the Mind's Eye," "Luminou Visions" and "Ancient Alien"). The effects that can be cr by cutting edge computer graphics are, as the saying goes "mind blowing." IN RUSS' MIND'S EYE: the geometric lines of the room coll fall away as we tumble, into the vortex, through the twis tube to the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's falling away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of crinkling cellphone, a rising tone, then,  suddenly, out of the tunnel the world explodes in splinte mandalas of pink, red, and orange. It is as Mircea Eliade wrote about the religious experience, "a complete rupture the mundane plain." The kaleidoscope of splintered colors trails like a fleet firebird giving way to an undulating SEA OF SERENITY. Off to the left, in the distance, lies the Ice Country, b we're not going there. A flock of strangely colored birds glide below, their trills merging with the music like a c We pass the waterfall where dead souls bathe. The effect is not unlike that of a child observing a thre ring circus: so much is happening, so much that we've nev seen before, all of it simultaneous -- and all of it so  astonishing. There's no way to absorb it all. One only wa with slack-jawed wonder. IN THE CLINIC: Hume watches as an Assistant takes Russ' b pressure. Russell sits unmoving, lost in time and space. IN HIS MIND'S EYE: a HIGH PLAIN appears in the distance;  approaching, it's green and welcoming. On the horizon, an eerie light glows. Small creatures scramble across the plain as we land. As  they approach we realize these are the ELVES, miniature  mutating folk radiating joy and playfulness. They're all  smiling. The grass grows tall, soon we're in an ancient overgrown  FORREST. The elves lead us through the darkening wood. A panther watches from a tree limb, his eyes piercing tre The music darkens, an ominous mood wells from the Earth's core. But the elves still seem happy and we follow, moving quic now. Out of the forest, on the valley floor, sits the SAUCER, source of the eerie glow. The silver skin pulsates like a living being. This is where the elves have been leading u but now, suddenly they're gone. The door to the saucer opens; a blue warmth radiates from within. A human silhouette appears in the doorway. We dra nearer. The silhouette is Evangeline, her arms across her stomach She pulls back her hands, revealing an open wound. Her ha are red with blood. IN THE CLINIC: Russ shifts in his chair anxiously. It's a if he's trying to get out of his body without standing up Hume checks the EKG monitor; Russ' heart rate increases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN HIS MIND'S EYE: Evangeline extends her hand, leads us  inside. The music, still hypnotic, has taken on a frighte Nine Inch Nails quality. Inside the saucer we're led from room to room. Shifting p of shades of blue surround us. The floors seem liquid at feet. He hears a TV show, "Jeopardy." Alex Trebek says "T Taj Mahal, Solomon's Palace and Billy Joel's beach house have this in common." Evangeline takes us to where a thirty year-old man stands wearing dark old jeans and a T-shirt. Hanging from one ha is a blood dripping butcher knife. This is the MURDERER. IN THE CLINIC: Russ squirms. Hume checks his watch; it's  been eighteen minutes. One of the other participants open his eyes, says something to one of the Assistants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop, stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN RUSS' MIND'S EYE: The murderer lifts his other hand. F his fingers tangles Evangeline's gold cross. He presses t cross into our palm. We fall into the WHIRLPOOL. IN THE CLINIC: Russell awakens, frightened, trembling, hi face beaded with sweat. Hume kneels beside him. Russ atte to speak, but cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the EKG monitor, double-checks with the Assis who is taking Russ' pulse, checking his pupil dilation. S indicates Russ is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groggy) We have to go to mother's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't do that. You're not fully  down yet. We'll go in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft, urgent) No, we've got to go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume attempts to calm him, but now Russ is on his feet,  pulling the EKG sensors from his chest, blood pressure cu from his arm. He starts for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go on my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ breaks free from the Assistant's attempt to restrain him, heads for the exit. Hume calls after:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I'll take you. Let's get  your shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume throws a perplexed backward glance to Garwood as he  follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, wearing his street shirt, rides shotgun as Hume  negotiates the Camry though a Portland suburban subdivisi Russ' eyes are focused on the road ahead. Classic rock pl on the FM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes Hume a moment to understand what his brother mea He clicks off the stereo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? What's this all about? (no reply) You're just going to sit there? I  mean, what can be so bad? You're not  going to create a scene are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn a corner: the house appears. Russ tenses. Hume pulls into the drive, parks behind their mother's va They get out, walk to the front door. At the door: Hume rings the chimes. No answer. Rings agai The brothers look to each other. Hume turns the knob: it' unlocked. The door swings open. They step inside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything appears normal, everything as it was the day  before. Russ and Hume walk into the living room. Day old cut flowers in their vase. Russell relaxes. Maybe it's nothing after all. Then, from the TV room, he HEARS A SOUND which sends a chill up his  spine: "Jeopardy." Alex Trebek's voice echoes from the den: "The Taj Mahal,  Solomon's Palace and Billy Joel's beach house have this i common." Buzzer sound. "Yes, Mike." Russ turns his head,  catching TV Mike as he replies: "They were all built for  love." Russ, now fearful, notices red stains on the carpet as th proceed. The bedroom door is ajar. It hits Hume: somethin is very wrong:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell pushes the bedroom door open, revealing a horrifi tableau. Evangeline, her stomach sliced open, her hands cut with  defensive wounds, her breast repeatedly punctured, lies b the bed. Everywhere, the room shows signs of a struggle: lamp knocked over, chair askew, coverlet half off the  mattress. Hume resists the impulse to rush to his mother's side. Ru his head in his hands, sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) Don't touch anything. It's a crime  scene. Mother, Mom, Mom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume steps closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice cracks) Yes. (beat) I'm going to another room, call 911.  Are you all right? I mean, to deal  with the police and whatever. I could  drive you home, come back and call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm all right. I'm down. Go ahead  and call. (beat) Hume?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? (no reply) Russell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paramedics wheel the gurney carrying Evangeline's body ba to an awaiting EMS vehicle. Police cars are parked at eve which angle. Crime scene tape fences off the front yard a officers hold back curious onlookers and media crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Russ sit on the chairs they occupied the day bef Across from them is Homicide Detective LAWRENCE, 40, a ve of such situations. Police and M.E. technicians go through the house with ord precision, collecting evidence. Glancing time to time at victim's sons, the technicians work as silently as possib

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'll be in touch tomorrow, Dr.  Rankin, but you touched nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door, we walked here, here,  there -- otherwise, nothing. I used  the phone in the den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were here yesterday. That's why  we came back. We had an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explains) We came to see Mom and, well, you  know, the usual parent-child stuff.  We wanted to patch it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you were together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father and my mother broke up  twenty... one years ago. She hasn't  seen him since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything, you can think  about it, was there anything unusual,  anything that might give us a  direction to pursue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was sick. She had lung cancer.  She had a mastectomy, but the cancer  returned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is this relevant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't. But, I mean, what kind of  person kills a dying woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incense burns at the foot of the shrine. Blue TV light  flickers from a TV across the room. Hume, Russell and Allison, somber, sit watching the video of Russ' trip. Hume holds a stapled EKG of Russ' minute-b minute progress. ON SCREEN: Russell, EKG wires under his smock, IV and cuf on his arm, lies quiescent on the Clinic lounge chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching the video) The grass grew and it was like a  forest, a jungle, there was a  panther...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning pages) Minute fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the elves lead me out of the  wood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of literature on elves.  Terry McKenna had a thing about them.  Spirit escorts to the Other World.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching himself on  screen) There, there, it's starting. I see  the saucer. I see the light. Blue  light. She's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON SCREEN: Russ, turning his seat, says: "Mom."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back in house) My God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Heart rate elevating. Blood pressure  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes me to him. I can see him  clearly. I see him in every detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison reaches over, touches Russ. ON SCREEN: Russ, squirming, saying: "Stop, stop."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He places her cross in my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON SCREEN: Hume kneels beside Russ. The trip is over. Rus sweating, opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-one minutes, EKG, blood  pressure returning to normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON SCREEN: Hume and Russell exit frame. The screen return to static. Allison, using the remote, clicks off the TV.  Russ sighs deeply. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... do you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ turns to a reluctant Hume. He extends his right arm, holds out his hand, which he has kept balled up, both her and in his mother's house, opens his hand, uncurls the  fingers, reveals his palm: there, on the tender part of h palm, is a BURN MARK of a cross, the exact size of his  mother's gold cross. They stare without response. Russ, wiping his wet eyes, stands:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away. Allison waits until Russ' door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitant) Yes, I do, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what it means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell sits beside Detective Lawrence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, no new developments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rankin, your mother's murder... (checks watch) occurred thirty-four hours ago.  Believe me, this is a high profile  crime. We are employing every resource  at our disposal-the forensic results,  a lot of it is still coming through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the evidence, witnesses, somebody  must have seen something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ' intensity can't help but pique the Detective's inte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've canvassed the neighborhood,  we're going back, re-interviewing --  gone out on the news shows, I'm sure  you've seen them. When's the funeral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (corrects him) Memorial service. (beat) Day after tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke with your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In England. That's where he lives. I  was going to have him interviewed  there, but he's decided to return  for the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell falls silent, not knowing what to say or feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean he didn't tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince Garwood, wearing a tweed jacket and tie, turning a  small Incan god in his hands, sits at his desk across fro Hume Rankin. The desk is stacked with research papers; the shelves lin with books on chemistry and psychedelic experience. A cha on one wall shows the chemical structure of various drugs TMA, MDMA, Mescaline, LSD, etc. A framed photo of Garwood and Ethan Rankin as young men sits on the bookshelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard and read a thousand trip  stories, I've been to a hundred  conferences, but I've never heard  anything like this. Glossolalia,  time and space travel, hyperspace  healing, eschatological hysteria,  material transformation, phone calls  to the dead, being devoured by giant  cats -- but not this. Are you going  to write it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't decided what to do. You're  the first one I've told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Russ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This whole thing has freaked him.  Apart from that, he's fine. Hell,  it's freaked me. It's hard to grieve  properly with this other stuff hanging  over our heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. I wish I could put it  in context for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this is not something we  discuss, but have you been in contact  with my father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police located him. He's going  to come back for the memorial service.  Doesn't that strike you as odd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (refers to Incan God) These were once high-tech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you've never heard from him,  about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but thinking back, everything  about your father was odd. There are  two paradigms for work in this field.  There are Huxleyites, who believe  psychotropic drugs are for the  prepared few. There are those like  Tim Leary who are popularizers, who  want everyone to turn on. I'm a  Huxleyite, Ethan was a Learyist and  he got terribly burned for it. Leary  didn't mind when they turned him  into a clown, in fact, he got off on  it; but not Ethan. He couldn't stand  the ridicule, the rejection, the  cheapening of his ideas. He turned  his back on the whole thing. I don't  know what your mother told you, but  I think this was underneath the  problems Ethan and Evangeline were  having.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fort Stevens State Park, formerly a military reservation, sits on a picturesque finger of land between the Columbia River and the Pacific Ocean. Friends and family of Evangeline Rankin stand under an op tent. Her smiling photograph rests on a stand to one side the tent; opposite is a table for refreshments. The conservatively dressed mourners stand in ranks as a  nondenominational MINISTER releases her ashes to the wind and sea. The words "Evangeline Rankin" permeate the fog o repression. A lone trumpeter plays "I Shall be Lifted Up." Hume, Russ, and Allison watch beside Ethan Rankin, now 61 wearing what can best be described as "gentleman farmer"  attire. Vince Garwood and his WIFE stands a row back. Russ glances at his palm: the cross burn mark is faint, a gone. TIMECUT: The bar is open. Friends and family mill about,  chat quietly, sip wine, coffee and Perrier. Ethan, avoiding Garwood, joins Hume and Russ. Allison wat as they step away from the others, view the great conflue of waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was very moving. She was a good  woman. Better than I deserved. I'm  glad I came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you did too. Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan reacts with a self-deprecatory smile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say I've been much of a  parent. (beat) I'm going back to Britain tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This takes the boys by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you stay a bit longer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) I almost came back five, six years  ago, but I did some checking. (to Hume) You're involved in psychedelics,  aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to the library, looked you  up. Read some of the articles you've  written. How in God's name did you  end up in that field? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (halting) Well, I was pre-med. I wanted to be  a doctor, just like you. I got  interested in brain function, how  neurotransmitters react, why certain  alkaloids effect the brain as they  do, which then of course led to  psychotropic drugs which led me here.  Just like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychedelics ruined my life and  they'll ruin yours too. Ruined my  reputation, ruined my marriage, ruined  my self-esteem. I have a new life  now and I want no contact with this  one. (hard: to Hume) Get out, Hume. Get out before it  ruins your life. (to both: voice  cracking) Maybe we'll meet again. We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ and Hume watch as their father, fighting back emotio walks a half dozen steps away, stares out at the ocean. Hume turns to his brother, stunned:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighter) Yeah, well, what do you expect from  a man who names his sons after British  philosophers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume drives his brother and Allison back to Portland. Russell thinking, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still see him. I can see him as  clear as I see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one inside the saucer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume starts to reply, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we have to do something about  it. What if he's a known psychopath?  What if he's killing someone else in  some other city right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you propose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, since I have the image so clear  in my mind, we could go to the police,  to Detective Lawrence. I'm sure they  have a sketch artist, you know, a  sketch kit, then they could take the  murder's face, see if anybody  recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if he's not the murderer?  What if it's just somebody you saw  somewhere and incorporated into you  unconscious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then he'll have an alibi, right? (Hume looks unconvinced) Hume, I think this is a real person.  We have a moral obligation to help  catch him. We have an obligation to  our mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ and Hume, in the darkened room, lean across the tabl facing each other. The conversation continues from the  previous scene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, we'll do it. We'll call Lawrence  in the morning. But we've got to  have the story straight. Russ states  the "official" version:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the DMT trial I had a vision.  I saw Mom bloody, I saw the murderer  standing beside her, holding a bloody  butcher knife. Afterwards, we went  over to her house and found her dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell him about the elves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you do, don't tell him about  the flying saucer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ leans beside a female POLICE SKETCH ARTIST working o computer. On the screen a face emerges from the many possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would say the eyes... show me some  additional eye choices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She brings up a screen full of white male eye matches; he picks one. She adds the new eyes -- much better. Almost a exact replication of the Murderer's face. Spooky. And  frightening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the skin color...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A utilitarian space: four walls, three chairs and a metal table. Lawrence, in a casual mood, sits across from the  brothers. In front of him is the open case file, Russ'  statement and the computer-generated sketch of the Murder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that expression, "I've seen  it all?" Remind me not to use it  again. (to Hume) Thanks for coming by. I thought it  would be good to go over it with  both of you. (indicates photo sketch) Is this a good resemblance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is, of course, trying to catch Hume unawares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have no idea. I was not  "there."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very good. Almost exact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pass it around, very discretely,  of course, given the circumstances.  See if it gets a hit. I don't think  broad dissemination is well-advised.  I checked with your department at  the University. Everything about the  drug trial is apparently on the up  and up. There won't be any negative  repercussions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this is him. This is the  killer. And he's real. I believe  that, I can't tell you why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that I won't tell you, it's  just that my reasons are more  intuitive than rational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawrence's beeper goes off. He checks it, turns to Russ:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're not planning on  participating in any additional  trials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that Lawrence is dense or insensitive, but he's  from another mindset. The Detective pages through Russ'  statement:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let me go through this again.  This DMT trip. Let's back up to the  point where you encounter the "self- transforming machine elves."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume looks at Russ incredulously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told him about the elves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, defensive, replies to Hume:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to. Otherwise it wouldn't make  any sense. How else could I explain  how I got to the saucer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (even more incredulous) You told him about the flying saucer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume's Camry, his mother's van parked in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single light burns. Hume, his legs folded in the lotus  position, meditates before the shrine. He repeats softly, "Om mani pene hung, om mani pene hung..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, wearing his Hamburger King shirt, his Hamburger Kin cap, his "Russell" name tag, takes orders from a gaggle o high school students.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume, Garwood and the Assistants collect EKG data, videot and notes after another DMT trial. A few participants lin talking amongst themselves. Russ steps silently in, raps his knuckles on the door jam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You about done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks around) Give me twenty minutes. I'll meet  you downstairs in the snack shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ nods, waves to Garwood, walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share coffee and soda water at a table in the upscal snack shop: designer coffee selection, croissants and sco vegetarian wraps and snacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police have unsealed Mom's house.  We have to arrange the disposition  of her possessions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the trial going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more freak-outs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding. Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police aren't doing anything. I  can't say I blame them, not after  that fiasco with Detective Lawrence.  I mean, we came off like a comedy  team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've spoken with Lawrence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to. Murders like this  are solved in seventy-two hours --  or not at all. Or at least not until  the killer makes a mistake. It's  been over a week. There's nothing in  the papers, on the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes me think you have something  in mind? You want me to get a copy  of the sketch? You want to circulate  it privately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murderer exists up here. (points to his head) So does, I imagine, his identity --  or at least, clues to his identity.  There's only one way to access that  information. That is to return to  the scene of the identification.  Learn more about him. (beat) To take another trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way Garwood would let you  back into the trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Besides, I don't want to  trip at the Clinic. That setting is  not good -- I'll do it at your place.  I'll smoke the DMT, not inject it.  Mix a little Syrian rue to extend  it. That way the experience will be  stronger, sharper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's illegal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drug use is based on loss of control.  Drug laws are created by those who  are terrified by loss of control --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're preaching to the choir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me you can't get DMT  crystals? This is the Pacific  Northwest, man. We're in the fucking  epicenter of drug consciousness. You  don't even have to go through the  Clinic. (no response) Or I should get it on my own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think will happen? (Russ doesn't  understand) When you trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back, Hume. He won't avoid  me. You know how the hallucinatory  mind works: you say the word "blue"  and you see more shades of blue than  you ever imagined. I'll call him,  he'll appear -- and when I meet him,  I'll find out more about him.  Something we can use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume exhales, sips his water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you do it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you should do it alone. (beat) I'd have to come with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'll think about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "setting" has been prepared: two mats, low indirect  lighting, a mounted camcorder. Russ, wearing shorts and a baggy T-shirt, sits on one of mats. Hume, similarly dressed, places a Goa Trance CD in stereo as Allison labels a video tape, puts it in the  camcorder. Hume takes the Haitian voodoo ceremony painting off the d room wall, turns it, places it on the floor, face to the  wall:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explains) I'd hate to look at that and up in  that trip. (to Russ) I opted to go without any carrier.  That way the effect will be strongest  and shortest. I think twenty minutes  is more than enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume carries a box containing a glass pipe, a small vial pale pink powder, herbs, a strainer and a small kitchen k to where Russ sits, places it on the floor, sits beside R Trance music -- mantra undulations laid over a gentle tec throb -- plays softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Allison) Is the designated driver ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Why is it the boys get to have all  the fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison checks through the camcorder -- the wide-angle le encompasses both brothers -- presses "record." The red li glows. She sits beside the brothers as Hume places DMT po in the bowl of the glass pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Russ) If you make an object, you say it  first, then I'll repeat it. (to Allison) Everything okay? (to Russ) Relaxed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume strikes a match, lights the powder, inhaling deeply. Hume reacts to the harsh chemical smoke as he passes the  pipe to Russell. Russ inhales, sets the pipe down, closes his eyes. Hume, feeling the onrush of drug effect, looks over to  Allison... The crackling, the rising tone AND THEY'RE OFF. Alan Watt described the DMT experience as "being fired out of the m of an atomic cannon." Note: although this is primarily Russ' trip, at times we' see both visions simultaneously on a split-screen. The camera snap zooms into each of their foreheads, throw out, in diptych, three time/space tunnels as they tumble  into the multi-colored VORTEX. The two simultaneously tumbling tunnels grow progressivel white until they merge, the entire screen luminescent, Ru face double exposed beneath: this is his vision. We fly across water, jewel-like crystals reflecting off i surface. To our right the promontory at Ft. Stevens State Park approaches, its earth heaving up, morphing into roll humps in a DESERT, which now surrounds us. Except it's liquid. The hump continues to grow, morphing  snake-like across the surface below. No, penis-like. In fact everything is SEXUALIZED. The tra clouds are breasts, buttocks, crotches, nipples. The screen caught between male and female imagery, separa yet intermixing. Vagina, penis; flower, serpent; yin, yan THROUGH THE CAMCORDER: Russ and Hume lying side by side.  Russ, left hand feeling his erection, reaches with the ot hand, touches Allison's leg, which protrudes into frame. removes his hand, places it on his side. IN RUSS' MIND: traveling through a world composed of movi body parts: hands, fingers, eyes, arms, yet human like so multi-limbed Hindu deity. Angel wings flap past as, somew a woman speaks to herself. Ganesh and the angel, now embracing, break off into a sep screen, vanish in the distance as the screens reemerge. A hand waves goodbye. Russ has forgotten the purpose of his voyage. He says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elves. (more forceful) Transforming machine elves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they appear, at first in the far distance, tiny speck on a VAST PLAIN of green. We approach. The topography feels familiar: we've been he before. It's the high plain from the clinic trip. Below  mutating elves, bouncing colored balls, wave and smile. To our left, the waterfall where dead souls bathe, ahead: recognizable glow. THROUGH THE CAMCORDER: Russ and Hume, side by side. Russe focused, says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The saucer. (beat) Open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN RUSS' MIND: the elves, at our sides, fall away as the  music grows more troubling, the SAUCER more imminent. Evangeline is at the door, bleeding, but we have no time her. Inside the saucer we wander through a maze of  multilayered blue light. Alex Trebek's voice echoes from TV speaker: "The Taj Mahal, Solomon's Palace and Billy Jo beach house have this in common." Russell's voice trails across the screen in colored patte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show yourself. I want to see you. (beat) Murderer. (beat) Murderer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, as if from vapor, the Murderer materializes, we old jeans and a T-shirt. In one hand is the bloody butche knife, in the other is Evangeline's cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume, recognizing Russ' voice, repeats the incantation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murderer, what is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN RUSS' MIND: the Murderer prepares to raise his hand, b it is not the hand bearing the cross -- it is the hand ho the knife. The Murderer steps forward, SLASHING THE KNIFE repeatedly toward us, into us. We hear a scream. THROUGH THE CAMCORDER: Hume screams as Russ, straddling h STABS his stomach and sides, with the kitchen knife. IN THE LIVING ROOM: Allison bolts across frame in a blur, screams as she pushes Russ off Hume, onto the floor besid Confusion, panic. Allison takes Russ' T-shirt, presses it on Hume's stomach attempting to help him. Hume, groggy, watches. Russ, becoming aware of what's happened -- seeing Hume, s his hands, seeing the knife -- retreats, frightened, acro the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Camry swerves wildly as it careens around a corner,  regains control, speeds down a residential street. Allison, at the wheel, drives as best she can given her  frightened condition. In the back seat, Russ cradles Hume in his arms. Hume's s and stomach are wrapped in bath towels; here and there bl seeps through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison, Hume and Russell burst through the door as one:  Hume, his towels nearly soaked through with blood, suppor by Russ and Allison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need help. Somebody, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads turn. An ORDERLY rushes over to help Hume while a N fetches a gurney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is going to be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Orderly and Nurse place Hume on the gurney as ANOTHER NURSE says to Allison:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need some information about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A uniformed OFFICER and a print JOURNALIST, standing toge watch from the waiting room. The Journalist has his note out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Officer) Isn't that... isn't that the Rankin  boys, the ones whose mother was  killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison speaks to the Nurse as Russ watches the Orderly r the bloody towels:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...not allergic to any medications,  Hume, Hume Rankin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE IN: a "below the fold" newspaper headline reads: "So of Murder Victim Involved in Stabbing" and, in smaller  typeface, "Acid Trip Alleged." The newspaper lies on a sm table beside a vase of flowers and hospital pamphlet ("Wh Emergency Strikes"). Hume rests in a private room, an IV connected to the back his hand. Allison, wearing a Fair Isle sweater, sits on a chair beside, reading. Hume opens his eyes. Allison, noticing this, stands besid the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear you come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few more days and you'll be able  to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Non-life threatening wounds, but,  Jesus, they hurt. (beat) Garwood visited yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was nice. What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was what he didn't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What didn't he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's under pressure. The whole  department is under scrutiny. I  offered to resign but he turned me  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, what it means is that it will  look better for the University if  they fire me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches his head, straightens his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I visited Russell in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hid the videotapes? (she nods) How's he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, what a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fallen inside himself. He's  absolutely mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told him I don't blame him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) But that's not the problem. The  problem is that he blames himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, wearing a blue prison jumpsuit, sits across from Detective Lawrence and District Attorney VANTIL. Russ' hands rest on the table. He can hardly bear to look them in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We in the DA's office have been back  and forth about this whole thing. I  know I said some pretty strong things  before, but we've reconsidered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell speaks in a small, broken voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't asked for leniency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if the District  Attorney's office wants to prosecute  the son of a recently murdered woman  who's killer is still on the loose. (looks at Lawrence) Especially when there is no  complainant, no reliable witnesses.  No hard evidence. (beat) I've spoken with the judge. I'm going  to propose community service and  probation, providing you enter a  court-administered program of therapy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any infraction, any contact with  illegal drugs, and you'll be right  back in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contrite) My drug taking days are over. No  more tripping for Russ Rankin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were trying to catch your mother's  murderer in hyperspace -- do you  realize how crazy that sounds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to get you some help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any developments in the murder  investigation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing from the sketch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what scares me the most,  even more than stabbing my brother? (they listen) It's the fear that this murderer is  a product of my own projection. That  I created him out of my own anger at  my mother, that I took on his form  and I killed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VanTil looks at Lawrence: this boy does need help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fortunate you have such a good  alibi at the time of her death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume, Allison and Russell exit the station, walk to the  parking lot. Hume, still sore, gets behind the wheel. Allison and Russ squeeze in; they drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison are up front, Russ in back. Hume relaxes happy to be out of the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison told me about the University.  I'm so --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Russ, I said no more  apologies. Just stop apologizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetic) I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can find another job, even if it's  sorting specimens somewhere. Or real  estate. What do you think? Think I'd  make a good realtor? (Allison laughs) I know these guys who have started  up a medical web site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, from hyperspace to cyberspace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camry on the drive. Trance music plays from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Insert of TV, the trip video: Russ, Allison and Hume lie the mats. Goa Trance plays over. Hume, coming in the back door, hears the TV, walks into t living room where Russ sits watching the trip video. On screen: Allison removes Russ' hand from her leg, place it at his side. Hume walks over to the video player, ejects the tape. The screen goes to static.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you find this? I'm going  to lock it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume turns off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to get better  watching that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I going to get better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell sits on the front steps, lost in thought. Allison opens the door, steps out on the porch, sits beside him. takes our a cigarette, lights it. She offers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment they just sit looking straight ahead, enjoyi the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where we were sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Hume. We were sitting here,  just like this, listening to the  crickets, sipping wine. That's when  I convinced him to let me in on the  DMT trial. That's how it all started.  If we could only go back... (she doesn't respond) Look, ah during the trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you and I, did I... was there  anything sexual?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were aroused. You touched me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You thought we did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trip was very... sensual. You  were part of it. Did you tell Hume?  I wouldn't want him to think, you  know, his brother and his girlfriend --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychedelics have a strong sexual  component. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have a sister. I've never  understood women, what makes them  tick. (beat) I don't even know what makes them  shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles) But it was good, right? It felt good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is supposed to help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's so much denial going on around  here, I think somebody ought to tell  the truth. I've never heard of therapy  that claimed that denial was the  doorway to health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctant, sheepish) Yeah, it felt good. I took a puff,  my arms and legs fell off, the floor  gave way and the world opened up.  Until, of course, the very end. That  wasn't good at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, think about the good. Not  the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ally, I like you. I think you're  fabulous, but I don't want you to  think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you too. I love you. But it's  Hume I want to give my life to. Why  can't both things be true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets this sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a smile) Do you have any sisters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs, responds with a mock drawl:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm the only one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE: Life goes on as usual, over music, something by contemporary psychedelic group, such as Flying Saucer Att or Shamen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, wearing his uniform, yaks it up with a couple of old timers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison lectures her high school students. On the blackbo behind her in bold capitals: "Nineteenth Century Literatu why is it relevant?" and I killed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume works at a computer cubicle, open texts stacked on h desk. A wall logo behind reads: "medicalanalysts.com."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garwood and the Assistants prepare participants for a dru trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Community service: Russ, strung alongside the roadway wit half dozen other orange-suited miscreants, picks up litte stuffs it into a sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, seated, listens while JUDITH SALBERG, the court- appointed therapist, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume meditates: "Om mani..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume, Allison and Russell pack Evangeline's possessions i cardboard boxes, saving some items, discarding others. Hume comes across photos of the young Ethan and Evangelin Rankin standing in front of their modest home, some alone some proudly displaying newborn sons. Hume passes the photos to Russ, who, after looking, hands them to Allison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Lawrence, on the phone, answers a question from fellow worker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell stands on the escarpment where his mother's ashes were strewn, where his father turned away to watch the  confluence of waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
