dialogues.text: The doorbell rings. Hume walks to the door, opens it: the standing in the failing light, is MIGUEL CHINDOY, an agin hippie, long braided hair, wearing a ruana, the short bla favored by South American peasants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Rankin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extends hand) I'm Miguel Chindoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (declines handshake) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've read about the events surrounding  you and your brother. I've come to  help. I have had twenty years of  shamanic experience. I believe I can  help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, who told you to come here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a shaman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a scholar. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come to offer my services. To  help your brother through this  difficult and necessary passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chindoy, thank you and fuck you.  Or is that Senor Chindoy? (checks car in driveway) So, Senor, get your ass back in your  rental car and leave us alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Rankin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume closes the door on Chindoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beer and TV sports joint on the University strip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: University rowdies cheer a sporting event on wall-mounted televisions as Hume and Garwood, tucked into a quiet corn sip draft beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Miguel Chindoy." His real name is  Michael Kamen. Born in Brooklyn,  1946. Poster child for burnout.  Brilliant student, apparently, but  then, arrested, discredited, etcetera.  Eight fries short of a Happy Meal.  We all talk the psychedelic talk,  spiel the psychedelic evangelism,  but there are people who are lost,  destroyed. We don't like to admit  it, but it's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep trying to contact me. I've  sent back my University mail, I  changed my mail address, but this is  the first time someone's tried to  track me down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about the way it came down.  It was improper, inhumane, and I was  part of it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had to do what you had to do. I  don't judge you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't play the saint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. I probably would have done  the same thing if I were in your  shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just hate having to be the one,  the proprietor of conservative  government sanctioned values.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working for an internet company,  I'm making some money for a change.  Maybe it was meant to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trial is going to be great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to ask about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've enough test subjects to start  collating the results. The final  paper -- that's a year off -- could  be quite important. I want to submit  it to Lancet. I know that sounds  like a fantasy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ? (Garwood nods) Everyone says he's getting better,  but I don't think so. He's in therapy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Court therapy. (Hume nods) The blind leading the mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've spent a lot of time with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've spoken with the therapist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Salberg? She says he's had a  "psychotic break."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell sits across from Dr. Salberg, 45, sincere. A Jung mandala hangs on the wall behind her -- right next to the photo of Sigmund Freud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it's hard to put into words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to me that at every turn,  you seek to avoid the underlying  issues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which underlying issues? Okay, let  me put it in terms you can understand.  I assumed another form and killed my  mother. I fucked my brother's  girlfriend, then tried to kill him.  Is that Oedipal enough for you? That's  just what I mean. Whenever this comes  up, you automatically assume this  metaphysical weight, strap it on  your shoulders like some Herculean  backpack with the implication that  you're guilty and there's nothing  you can do about it. You did not  fuck your brother's sister. You did  not kill your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) Somebody killed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been taking your medication?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been three weeks. You should  feel something. Can you detect any  change?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still have suicidal feelings? (no answer) I would like to change your  medication. It's an exploratory  process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up a script pad, starts to write:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prozac is a relatively mild drug. A  friend of mine calls it the penicillin  of psychiatry. It's not working and,  frankly, I only hoped it would. I  want to try something else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume, followed by Allison, opens the front door and, sett down his keys, reacts with shock at what he sees: the hou has been trashed, burglarized. He looks around: furniture tossed this way and that. The  Buddha toppled over, the shrine desecrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, Hume...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up the video player which has been tossed to th floor. They stand in a sea of discarded books. Hume goes into the KITCHEN. The refrigerator door is open, the cabinets exposed. Ther he sees, amid the maliciously discarded food supplies and dining utensils, a once locked cabinet, now chopped open, its lock ripped out. Hume examines the cabinet -- its contents tossed hither a yon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I locked it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The video tape. The trip tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, driving home, listens to rap on the car radio. The music distorts. Russell feels something strange. He l side to side. It suddenly feels like he's driving too fas He slows his mother's van to a crawl, turns off the radio He sees something darting in the distance, something in t trees between one house and the next. Russ pulls the van to the curb, stops. Shuts off the engi Silence. He gets out of the van, closes the door. Looking apprehensively, he steps forward... Then he sees him: THE MURDERER, the Murderer from the blu light saucer, tucked behind a distant tree. The Murderer  scans the landscape. Russ devises a method of escape. If he dashes to the righ hides behind a tree, then slips between two houses, he ca avoid the Murderer. He runs. He escapes. Ahead: Hume's house. He's home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, composing himself, walks up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell enters to find Hume and Allison cleaning up the l room mess. Russ attempts to appear the voice of reason:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were burglarized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some creep broke in. That's how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. We're still looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ looks at the toppled Buddha:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would he do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's missing. Nothing  valuable. We didn't have anything  fucking valuable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fault. Ever since --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you fucking get off that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume replaces the Buddha on its pedestal as Russ drifts i the kitchen. He calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with this guy? He's got a  thing for Special K and Wheat Thins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison join him in the KITCHEN. Russ, suddenly  pale, points to the splintered kitchen cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was taken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the cabinet. The locked cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are reluctant to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where I'd put the tape. (Russ: huh?) From the trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ starts manically pacing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's found us, he knows we're onto  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murderer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's some sort of joke,  right? Well, fuck both of you! He  knows about all of us, he knows about  the police sketch, he knows  everything! It's evidence. Lock the  doors! We've got to get some guns,  protect ourselves. He wants to kill  us, because we know who he is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison goes over to Russ, attempts to hold him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll sort it out in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disdainful) Right, like they're going to do  anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's been no real damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're exhausted. You look fried.  Now is not the time to jump to  decisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her embrace calms him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I suppose. (beat: weepy) I don't know what gets into me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right? We can take you  somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I'm just tired, worn to the  bone. Every little thing, I don't  know why, sets me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume looks out the window, toward the driveway and street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mom's van?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ran out of gas. I left it several  blocks back. (off Hume's puzzled  reaction) I walked. I'll get it in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to be all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I just need some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts for his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to help clean up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got it under control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ nods, staggers away. Hume and Allison look at each o as he walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison, outside, waits at the curb as a friend stops her car. She gets in, the car drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Russ, at the kitchen table, finish morning coffe peruse a scattered newspaper. Russ, resigned, sets down h cup:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I better go track down  the car, pick up some gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume, checking his watch, watches Russ exit. The door sla Assured he is in the house alone, Hume stands and -- chec the window -- walks to his brother's guest room. Hume looks around his BROTHER'S ROOM. Where to start? Everything seems normal: Russ' dirty clothes thrown into corner, bed sheets unmade, a book (Stephen Wright's Non Z overturned on the bed table beside an empty glass. Recently recovered photos of his mother, father, himself Russell on the bureau. These cause Hume to hesitate, but continues: opening drawers, going through the closet, loo under the bed. And there, under the bed, hidden, he finds it: the trip v tape. His fears confirmed: it was Russ who "broke in," trashed house, desecrated the shrine, stole the video from the ki cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume watches, waits as high-schoolers stream from the two story building. Then Allison appears, walking beside a fellow teacher, jo She sees Hume beside the Camry, walks over, embraces him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a surprise. You're my "crossing  guard" now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that feels good. I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She, sensing something of import, opens the passenger doo gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in the Camry. Hume makes no attempt to start the car. She waits apprehensively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I searched Russ' room. I found the  video tape. (beat) There can be no other explanation.  It was Russ. He broke into the house,  he trashed everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He claimed it was the murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what this means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's no longer in control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my brother. I love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck help. I know about the help  he's getting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he in danger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that wasn't like a casual  question. That was a real question.  Is he in danger? Are we in danger  from him? Can he hurt us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fast food joint in a row of fast food joints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow day: a few workers, moms and kids. Russell, cap and name tag in place, flirts with a pretty, intellectual COED. He holds up a french fry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The french fry. My occipital lobe  sees it, my temporal lobe says "yum,"  my parietal lobe says, "I'll eat  it," my prefrontal lobe says, "I'll  bite it," my motor cortex does so... (takes bite of french  fry) ...my somesthesic cortex supervises  and my brain is thrilled. (Coed laughs) My brother taught me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't eat fried food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To each her own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a strange sort of guy to be  working at a place like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm working my way up to middle  management.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs again) I'm working my way up to a grilled  chicken sandwich and a diet coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That we can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ turns to order a grilled chicken sandwich, turns and smiles at the Coed. Then he sees: past the Coed, past the brightly colored tables, moms and kids, through the windo lurking outside, wearing old jeans and clean T-shirt, the MURDERER beside a four-wheel drive pickup. It's a face he knows well, one he can't forget. The Murderer walks toward the entrance, turning his head, if looking for someone. Russ turns his head away, says "I'll be right back" to a  fellow worker as he scoots into the kitchen area. The Coe baffled, watches. He ducks out a side door, circles surreptitiously along t SIDE OF THE BUILDING. Peeking around the corner, he sees Murderer just standing there by the concrete table and ch hands on hips, looking around. The Murderer, turning his back to Russ, decides to go ins Russ inches closer, following him. The Murderer ENTERS Hamburger King. Russ slips through th door behind him. The Murderer scans the room: he's looking for someone. Russell makes his move. Taking a running start, he charge toward the Murderer, tackles him at the waist, drives him against a chair, then onto the floor. Russ is now atop the Murderer, turning him over. Patrons  stop mid sentence, mid meal, look speechlessly -- as if i slow motion dream. Russell pummels the Murderer's face, blow after blow afte blow. A child screams. A male employee and two patrons rush over. They pull Russ off the Murderer. The Murderer's face is bruised, starting to bleed. He is  terrified, BUT: he is not the Murderer. In fact, it's not even a man. It's a woman. Commotion, chaos. Someone calls out, "Call the police." Russ, restrained by the employee and patrons, looks at th "Murderer." He can't understand how his face transformed  into this bloodied female visage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison sit across from Salberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They initially gave him haloperidol --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haldol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's out of my hands, Dr. Rankin.  It's not my case. It's up to the  staff at the psychiatric hospital.  But I would imagine they would  prescribe orally administered  Thorazine, at least until they can  be sure he's not a danger to himself  or others. (beat) I'm sorry I wasn't of more help. I  knew he was delusional but I didn't  think he was hallucinational. He  sees things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he sees things. Just because  they put him in an institution doesn't  mean he's going to stop seeing things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has deeply unresolved issues  concerning his father -- and his  mother. And you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (derisive exhale) And Thorazine is going to fix that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thorazine will block the  hallucinations, but, in all the  literature, it's never proven  effective against delusions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words, he'll still believe  in his delusions, he just won't see  them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But, as I said, it's no longer  my case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever considered this: Russ,  because of his use of psychedelics,  has passed through the doors of  perception, gained access to another  reality and for one reason or another  is unable to integrate this reality  with his present state?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison gives Hume a look, places her hand on his arm -- he's sounding crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's called schizophrenia. And  it's not treatable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bucolic campus setting belied by a sign reading, "Glenv Psychiatric Institute."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A day has passed. Allison and Hume visit Russell, wearing institutional whites, in an artificially "homey" room. Russ struggles to have a normal conversation, counteracti the effects of the Thorazine like a wrestler in a hold. H sips from a glass of water:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Allison) You can smoke here, you know. It's  ironic. In all of Portland, there's  no place you can have a smoke, but  here it's all right. I guess they  figure we got nothing to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine Russ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to help you, but  unfortunately, you've fallen into  the great maw of the legal system.  We've hired a lawyer, a psychiatric  advisor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all paperwork and bullshit. If  I had a prayer, it would be, "God,  let me never fall prey to the US  criminal justice system."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must not lose faith. We're here  for you. You are loved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ' hands tremble. He restrains them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just these side effects, these --  what's the word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extrapyramidal disorders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that and the dry mouth. (beat) I want to be normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him. (no response) The murderer. I can't get out of  here. He must have figured out by  now where I am. I'm not exactly  protected in here. He could slip in,  you know, wearing a uniform, find  me, kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if it's possible, but  you need to make an effort. The mind  is an extraordinarily powerful organ.  You can, Russ, if you apply your  mind, wipe all the events surrounding  Mom's murder out of your mind. You  can make the murderer disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, not responding to his brother's plea, sips water shifts subjects:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think time is a thing. It's not an  abstraction. Time not only changes,  but there are different kinds of  time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, this is interesting but it is  not where we should be concentrating  our efforts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An INSTITUTIONAL AID sticks his head into the room, withd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that's a hint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at bare wrist) If I had a watch, I could tell you.  They must have some exciting activity  planned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ motions Hume close, speaks into his ear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgent) Get me out of here. He's going to  find me. He's going to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume kisses his brother on the cheek, stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Allison) Ally, when you get outside and into  the car, do me a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke a cigarette for me. That's  what's nice about being crazy. You  smoke out there, I can taste it in  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Vince Garwood stand outside a pleasant post-war  home in South Park. Garwood's wife works in a bricked-off flower garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a walk. There's a little  park up the way. I find that when  something really heavy is weighing  on you, it's good to walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nod to Vince's wife, head down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm losing my brother. They got him  on Thorazine. It's all maintenance  crap. His mind is melting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have contacts at Glenview, people  I've consulted with over the years.  I've asked about Russ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you grow up with a brother,  all that sibling shit, you don't  think much about it. Of course we  were close, not having a father, but  I never realized how much I loved  him until all this happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about it too, in  ways that probably go far and beyond  what you're thinking. Ways that go  back to your father, to the very  reason I got involved in this  discipline. You know how it is in  this dreadful field. You get into  psychedelic drugs, you have to be  prepared to give everything else up.  The medical establishment turns its  back on you, any hopes you had of  wealth are gone; of the people who  take you seriously, half are fucking  crazy. You do it because you believe  in it. You believe that this sad  planet, if there is any hope for it  all, its hope lies in some primal  reconnection with psychotropic plants.  Every religion, you trace it back,  you find a bunch of primordial men  sitting around a campfire chewing  leaves. (beat) I went to see your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, off the record. I feel  responsible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach a small pocket park, sit on a bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you prepared to hear what I really  believe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point, I'm prepared for about  anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother has had what others  would call a "psychotic break," and  it's not a condition that's going to  be improved by conventional medication  or therapy. I see no hope in that  direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're losing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has caused me to go back through  the literature, tests, theories. I  guess what I'm proposing is  psycholytic therapy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Psychedelic therapy." No one's done  that for years. It's been discredited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was not discredited. It was  criminalized. Extraordinary things  were being accomplished, Stanislav  Grof, Humphrey Osmond, but then came  the anti-establishment movement, the  popularization of LSD and the Big  Crackdown. Psycholytic therapy just  stopped. No one wanted to lose their  license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what happened to my father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues) There is a Shaman down the Amazon  from Iquitos, near the  Peruvian/Columbian border, Don Macita.  He works with the ayahuasca vine.  Your father and I tripped with him  many years ago. We correspond from  time to time. His books of imagery  are essentially the same as what  Russ describes. He's been doing this  all his life. He works in the jungle,  using the old ways, which is the  best way to experience these primal  drugs. It's the only way to ingest  heroic doses of psychedelics -- in  their natural context. It has the  added benefit of being legal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Define "heroic."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're talking about ayahuasca,  the mother of all harmala alkaloids,  I'd say, oral dose, five, six hundred  milligrams. I'd have to talk to Don  Macita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's life threatening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are different ways to mix the  actual brew, which then effects the  nature of the journey. I don't think  we should wait. Much longer, it may  be too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second. You're assuming I've  already signed onto this "back to  the jungle" scheme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would need your support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. You don't have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, shivering, sits squeezed into the corner of his roo Sweat beads his forehead, his pupils are dilated. Every noise from outside, from the corridor, from the roo above is magnified in his mind. He is struggling to hold to his sanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a normal house on a normal block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light filters in from a street lamp. Hume and Allison lie each other's arms. It's as if they must hold on to each o for dear life because they're all they have left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was an inmate at a prison for  the criminally insane and he told an  interviewer, "It's easy to make the  cops think you're crazy. All you  have to do is act crazy all the time."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if the same is true about  sanity. All you have to do is pretend  you're sane all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, you've got me fooled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is such a thin tissue separating  one reality from another, from here  and now to somewhere else and some  other time. Somewhere this is not  happening to us, but we are here and  it is now and it is happening. (looks to ceiling) When we had the wake, when we  distributed my mother's ashes, my  father came over and spoke to me. He  said, "Psychedelics ruined my life  and they'll ruin yours."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father knows best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume emits a short derisive snort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Garwood want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He called, you went over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks) It was nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison turn up the leafy drive. Several police  cars are parked out front. They park, pass the police cars, head inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison step up to the main reception desk, spea to a RECEPTIONIST in a white uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Dr. Rankin. We have a two o'clock  visitation with Russ Rankin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait as the Receptionist speaks into the phone. The  entrance area is designed to be hospitable, but, looking  closer, one realizes that beneath the benign surface is a high security institution: multiple locks, triple depth g The corridor door opens with a buzz. A hospital ADMINISTR and a uniformed POLICE OFFICER approach them. They realize something is wrong with Russ. They greet:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened? It's Russ, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Rankin? (Hume nods) I'm Dr. Fielding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been trying to reach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were running errands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you have a cell phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't like cell phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Administrator lets this (her attitude) pass:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid, ah, we can't find your  brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, "can't find him?"  He's in a lock down ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At morning call, the attendant brought  him breakfast. The room was empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could he be hiding in the building  somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Security is going through every room,  ward, office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are interviewing the staff. Someone  let him out. There's no other  explanation. You haven't heard from  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any idea where he might be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume rings the Garwood doorbell. Mrs. Garwood answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Garwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smile) Hume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to speak to Vince. I tried at  the University.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a phone call. Somebody at  a conference dropped out and they  asked Vince to fill it. He packed,  grabbed his passport and headed for  the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music plays over as Hume, pulling the curtains, looks out the front window at an unmarked police car across the str with two PLAINCLOTHESMAN sitting in front. He turns back into the room, walks over to Allison. He sp softly, telling her about Garwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign on the window reads: "Lennon's: We'll Find It" w a cartoon of a detective type holding an oversized magnif glass. Through the window: Hume and LENNON, 30, lean over a comp manned by a teenager computer NERD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lennon speaks as they look at the screen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It took a bit of doing. Your friend  didn't go direct. Portland to Mexico  City, re-ticket to Bogota, to Quito,  to Iquitos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any other passengers? I mean any  passenger on the same flights with  Garwood. (to computer Nerd) Can you do that? (the Nerd goes to  work) Used to be, in the day, you had  expenses, man hours, gumshoes, now  it's just a computer and a teenager  with a knack to hack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a reappearing name for the  first two flights. "John Russell."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garwood's voice starts over as the Nerd continues to work

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the people of the Amazon basin,  all life is determined by countless  spirits and beings who live "on the  other side." It is essential for  their own survival to be able to  enter that world and interact with  those spirits to secure well-being  for oneself and one's family...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garwood and Russell sit in a coffee/snack shop in Iquitos frontier jungle city of 350,000 inhabitants in Southeaste Peru. Outside, along the single-story streets, motokars (motorc taxis), emit clouds of pollutants as they pass. Inside,  mestivo kids, wearing Nikes and NBA T-shirts, play X-men  combat video games. Not exactly one's preconception of  "Amazonia." Garwood continues speaking as Russ sips coffee, bites fro bread roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They get this protection through  the ayahuasca ceremony. The  preparations, drinking the brew, the  visions, the assistance of an  ayahuasquero, a shaman. Huasca means  vine, aya means souls or dead people,  so it's the vine of the dead or the  vine of the spirits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison, wearing jeans, nylon jackets, hiking bo and backpacks, exit, nod to the Plainclothesmen in the ca across the street, get into the Camry and drive off. Hume's voice over picks up where Garwood's left off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it's in the elite company of the  most powerful naturally occurring  psychotropic drugs, the harmaline  alkaloids: ayahuasca, psilocybin,  yage, iboga. DMT is the active  ingredient in ayahuasca. Chacruna, a  natural MAO inhibitor, makes it orally  active, extends the effect. It's  essentially a very long DMT trip...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand at the American Airlines counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...nothing prepares you for it. It's  the great unknown. The drug looks  inside you and takes you there. The  Jungian maps don't apply. Your chakras  are of no use. It's a big forest and  there are no markers on the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison, sitting next to Hume, asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's the reason I support  naturally occurring psychedelics. If  they were dangerous, their use  wouldn't have endured this long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But is it dangerous for Russell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince and Russ sit in a canopied river boat as it putt-pu down river. Around them sit mestivo peasants, a tourist c and a local business type. Garwood's voice over resumes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don Macita, the shaman we will meet,  he's over seventy now, has a camp in  the jungle. He believes the body is  full of toxins and these toxins will  emerge as demons unless purged. The  preparations include four days of  cleansing, external and internal,  diet and meditation. It involves a  sort of mud bath, drinking a diuretic  tree sap, oye, eating yucca and rice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ turns to Garwood, says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I thought the ayahuasca brew is  purgative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. The first couple hours, "la  purga," is vomiting and shitting.  The visions will start at this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're taking this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We both are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison, tired, emerge into bright Amazonian sun line of motokars vie for their attention. Garwood's voice resumes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will use this period to concentrate  on our goals. We will define your  areas of conflict, define the person  you want to be when the journey  ends...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison stand in Plaza de Armas, approach likely strangers, struggle with their Spanish, get replies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...At first you will feel like you're  dying. You'll have to endure this.  That's what the drug is about: dying  and living...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garwood and Russell approach the Amazonian encampment. It virtually unchanged from forty years before. The Ceremoni House stands in the distance. And, ahead, beside the river, the small figure of Don Mac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You will enter the wholeness of  being. You will feel a satisfaction  like you've never known...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don Macita turns, looks. Vince waves to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison negotiate with a guide on the riverside  walk. Charter boats wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...First come the patterns, then  plants, then animals, then fantastic  architecture, the little people,  they are guides -- and, at some point,  the serpent. Don't be afraid. He is  a passage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison ride down the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the end, well, it will be  idiosyncratic. It will be what you  are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince and Russell stand, nude, as huito, a bluish fruit p mixed with clay, is poured, rubbed over their bodies by D Macita and his native ASSISTANT. The same blue that caked Garwood years before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The brew is made by mixing crushed  ayahuasca vine with alternating layers  of chacruna leaves and boiling them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garwood, Russ and others watch as Don Macita, 77, selects section of the climbing ayahuasca vine, instructs his  Assistant which portion to cut with his machete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the duration, including the  purging, will last six to eight hours,  although the intensity will slack  off after four or five hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Allison step off the river boat, look around. A  path leads to the Ceremonial Hut, the open MAIN HOUSE hun with hammocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garwood and Russell watch as Don Macita and his Assistant prepare the ayahuasca brew: crushing strips of vine, layi them in an old metal pot. Atop the small table, like forty years before, sits the  ceremonial bowl, its sides painted and repainted over the years with fantastic imagery, rainbow bands of brightly  colored unreal creatures. Hume and Allison approach. Garwood greets them  enthusiastically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume! Ally!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same thing you're doing here. (to Don Macita) Don Macita, this is Hume Rankin,  Russ' brother I told you about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume exchanges greetings with Don Macita as Russ walks ov whom, he in turn greets. Hume turns to Vince, speaks soft censorial:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison, taking the hint, says to Russell:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand at the edge of the Amazon, brown slow-flowing  water, perhaps fifty meters wide. Around them, the jungle vibrates with life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you've done is illegal. I could  report you. You could go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that has to be, it has to be.  Just wait until we've done what we  can for Russ. There's a program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You absolutely baffle me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garwood glances to the Main House where Allison and Russe walk, talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done a lot of things I regret  in my life, and a lot of the things  I regret involve your family. When  your father was vilified, when the  witch hunt hit, he came to me for  support and I turned my back on him.  I protected my position. He left the  country, left his family. I took the  easy way when letting them fire you.  Now this. I feel my life is defined  by the sadness in your family. I  believe I can help your brother. He  was dying in there. (a beat) It's so good you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To help Don Macita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're tripping as well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) I wasn't sure before, but now I am.  I want to apologize to your father.  His spirit is all around here. Come,  you've got to talk to Don Macita.  We'll go over the counseling --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think I ought to talk to  Russ first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume and Russell sit inside the hammock strung house.  Generations of visitors have left inscriptions and painte mystic, hallucinatory symbols (the Third Eye, the Serpent on the beams and benches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought along your meds, just in  case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding. That stuff is poison.  It's poison for the brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know, I just felt it would  be irresponsible not to. I didn't  know what condition you would be in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That last night in the sanitarium, I  was holding on, just barely,  concentrating every atom in my body  to remain sane, like those kids in  "Nightmare on Elm Street" trying not  to sleep. Then I heard the door open --  he had come for me, the murderer,  but it was Professor Garwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this cleansing and my  conversations with Don Macita have  cleared my mind. Everything is now  directed toward the journey. I am  prepared. I want to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume gives his brother a loving look, then a big embrace, which is returned and held.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going in anger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember this journey you're taking,  this drug, what it's doing it's doing  for your benefit. Pay attention. It  wants to help you. (Russ nods) You know how I like to say they're  not recreational drugs? That's not  true. They are recreational. Re- creational. You must re-create your  life. Remake it, heal it. (Russ nods again) If you get lost, if you get  frightened, if you're in danger,  repeat the mantra. If you hear me  saying, "Om mani pene hung," you'll  know that I'm with you, you're not  alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume reaches in his pocket and hands Russ a small souveni replica of an elf-like Incan god, much like the one Garwo had in his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, take this. I bought this in  Iquitos. It didn't cost anything.  It's supposed to bring good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ tucks it into his pocket:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only it were that easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garwood and Russell, wearing white ceremonial ruanas, sit where Vince sat with Russ' father years before. Don Macit ladles out the ayauasca brew into two cups on the table. cup contains almost twice as much brew as the other. Don Macita blows purifying smoke on Garwood and Russell. Allison and Hume sit to the side. He puts his arm around shoulders. Russ looks at his fingernails: they are rimmed blue from purifying dye. Don Macita places the cup with the larger dose in Russell hands, the other in Vince's, then steps and begins to sin the soft, lilting icaros: "Maimandara shamuirimum, Yana p chicunaca..." TIMECUT. Night. Garwood and Russell both bent over a long basin, vomiting. "La Purga." Russ watches his vomit as the camera zooms toward his eye enters his myriatic pupil. INSIDE RUSS' MIND: his vomit emerges as blood, covering t floor, liquefying it. In the blood swim thousands of vibr worms. The characteristic crackle, the rising hum (DMT particles crashing into the brain's synapses) as the worms, animate like sperm, jump bullet-like from the bloody below, pierc our skin. The voyage has begun. Russell's pupil expands, revealing the vast geography of  hyperspace. Space first appears as GEOMETRIC FORMS, revolving  kaleidoscopically. These quickly assume vegetable form, an inviting cardinal red CHRYSANTHEMUM, its petals beckoning, becoming a white LOTUS blossom. Into the blossom we fly, its core opening onto the JUNGLE canopy. We fly over the jungle, compelling images filling our fie of vision: birds unlike any ever beheld, rippling trees a fauna, indistinguishable creatures in the undergrowth. To our left: the waterfall where dead souls bathe. We are the panther. We know this because we hear the pant heart beating, hear its paws pounding the earth's surface see its paws before us. We dive toward the surface. Into the jungle the panther  plunges. But it is not a jungle, it is an OCEAN and we are under t water now, swimming shark-like alongside pink dolphins an glowing fish of the deep. Great primordial creatures, sea monsters extinct for eons, pass. We burst from the ocean Atlantis-like into a realm of RUI PALACES and LABYRINTHINE CITIES. Empty unpopulated empire rise and fall. African mud cities become Palantine temples; pyramids bec decayed skyscrapers. Throughout melodies mix with the music, snippets of sound contemporary and archaic. A guitar riff from the Fifties, bit of Beethoven, third world instruments. Then, for a moment, above the ruins: a cascade of ADVERTI IMAGERY: the pop culture of signs, slogans and logos rush past. In the ruined cities, we enter the HALL OF ANCESTORS. We our shadow before us, morphing the history of earth's lif forms: sea-going, reptilian, mammalian, ape-like, humanoi The ancestors are stacked in high-rise rows to our right left. All of mankind's faces, Neanderthal, Homo-sapien,  yellow, white, black -- some surprised, some merely curio morphing one to the other like falling dominos. At the top level, we notice, are the gods -- primitive,  ancient unrecognizable divinities yielding to more famili figures: the Egyptian hierarchy, the Greek pantheon, Nord gods and goddesses, the manifestations of Buddha, the Hin cosmology, Mohammed and his followers, Christ and the sai yet, looking closer, we see they are in pain, all writhin like crucified Jesuses. Not gods, daemons. We grow frightened:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hume, Hume... om mani...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE CEREMONIAL HOUSE: Hume cradles his brother, repeat with Russ:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...pene hung, om mani pene hung...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSIDE RUSS' MIND: we burst from the Hall of Ancestors, f over a great SAVANNA. There we see them, first as mottled dots, growing larger we near: the self-transforming machine elves. And they see us. Recognizing our approach, they emit a  communal joyful "ahh." The sound's after-image sails acro the savanna like a green shooting star, trailed by a  chartreuse neon echo image. The elves bounce brightly colored balls or are brightly  colored balls. It's hard to tell, because they constantly transform into the balls, back into themselves. Garwood's voice echoes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are guides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saucers fly in a flurry overhead like comets: oval shaped then chrysanthemum, then lotus, then oval again. Coming closer, walking amongst the elves, they offer us g they toss their colored balls, which, as they touch us, t into extraordinary objects: iridescent Faberge eggs, morp by the sound of their voices into essences whom, it seems are ideas themselves. It feels wonderful. All of which distracts us from a distant specter approach at warp speed: the great speckled serpent. Time motion cl speed overhead, transforming the savanna into an endless  DESERT. It's the rapacious serpent from Ethan Rankin's jungle tri The serpent's jaws open wide, revealing rows of razor-sha teeth, a crimson red mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Om mani pene hung...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We try to escape but cannot. We plunge past the teeth, do the esophagus, into the belly of the beast -- the "animis roller coaster ride." IN THE CEREMONIAL HOUSE: Hume and Don Macita sit beside R

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSIDE RUSS' MIND: down and down we tumble, past reptilia ribs and pulsing organs. We suddenly emerge amidst a blaze of color, not in a Mexi City rave club, but in a blue throbbing room. We are in t SAUCER. Multi-dimensional walls of mutating shades of blue surrou us. Up, down, right, left, each indiscernible from the ot Alex Trebek's voice: "The Taj Mahal, Solomon's Palace and Billy Joel's beach house all have this in common." Growing, in the distance, a woman lying on a hospital bed is she being operated on or giving birth? We know it's ou mother, but do not say that word. A heavy metal grate falls before us, keeping the woman ou of reach. The Murderer materializes through the grate, wearing, as  before, jeans and a T-shirt. His face, however, seems different: cruel, mean, distorte In his hands he tosses two balls: the miniature heads of  Hume and Russell. The Murderer's eyes ooze puss, blood drips from his ears nostrils. His expression is demonic. Behind him, through the grate, the hospital room, now red is a torture chamber: a Boschian tableau of medieval pain and suffering. The woman in the hospital bed lies next to wretched creat on racks and wheels. Black hooded inquisitors lean over h chest, employ instruments of torture. The Murderer squeezes the miniature heads as his own head swivels, Exorcist-like, on his base. He is now Ethan, ins crawling from every facial orifice. In his hands the knife and cross. We are terrified. The music is terrifying: discordant noi and a cacophony of angry indistinguishable voices. In the distance, Hume's voice struggles to be heard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Om mani pene hung...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And also, somewhere in the music, a repeat of an earlier  voice: "What is your name?" We try to repeat the mantra, the words come out wrong. Ethan's head swiveling again, revealing our own image, Ru face, who is now, suddenly upon us, knife upraised, slash slashing. Russ' chest opens, he is inside us. We stand in a HALL OF MIRRORS, our image reflected over a over again. We are The Murderer, we are Ethan. And behind us, in every duplicating reflection, behind th iron grate, the red chamber of horrors -- and a woman's  scream. Our reflection stands at the door, preventing entry. A tug at our side: it's one of the smiling elves. He offe us a colored ball. We look again, the elf is gone. The brightly colored ball glows, continually morphing hum and animal images, ancient and contemporary. We throw the ball at our reflection, hitting first one  reflection, then the others in a rippling chain effect. Our image transforms into an angry mass of wasps, which,  buzzing, fly away, diminishing in size until they are not more than faint gold crosses in the distance. The cacophony subsides, a voice emerges from the chaos:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were all built for love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grate lifts with a Mozartian cresendo. The torture ch is again shifting shades of blue. We walk to the hospital bed, pull back the sheet which co the woman on the bed. Her chest is exposed X-ray-like: ribs, a beating heart an lungs. And, in one lung, a diseased black cancerous clump crawling with maggots. We reach in, forcefully yank out the clump, toss it heave where it bursts into brightly geometric forms, flies away The woman on the bed -- she is our mother -- smiles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blue dot appears on her forehead like a Third Eye. Musi welcomes us as we move toward the dot until it fills our  field of vision. We hyper-zoom into the blue dot, earth. Recognizable  configurations appear, North America, the Pacific Northwe Oregon, Portland, downtown... Until the dot is nothing but a large human eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights come up on a reostat. Hume, wearing a blue button  down collar shirt with a dark tie, in the lounge chair. An Assistant extracts the IV line from Russ' arm prepares remove the EKG sensors. Garwood steps over as the Assistant goes to help another  participant in the DMT trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a moment for Russ to orient himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks) Idiosyncratic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the amazing thing. Every  experience is absolutely unique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, still somewhat stunned, stands, says to Hume:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go over to Mom's house. I want  to apologize for that stunt I pulled  the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still groggy. And you've got  to do the questionaire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Camry and van in the drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day old cut flowers sit in a vase. Evangeline, Hume and Russell sit across from each other,  cradling cups of Kona coffee. "Jeopardy" plays on the TV in another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so amazing you came over. I was  just getting ready to call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to explain. (they wait) Dr. Klein called. He had gotten the  latest x-rays. I didn't understand.  I called him back to be sure. He  repeated it. (voice cracks) The tumor is diminishing. It's  responding to treatment. It's almost  gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys stand, embrace her jointly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's miraculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait to tell Ally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ reacts to a particularly loud burst of applause from the TV:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you stand to have that thing  on all the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just background noise. It's  comforting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ steps into the DEN, turns off the TV, interrupting A Trebek mid-sentence. Russ feels something in his jeans, reaches in his pocket, pulls out a small replica of an elf-like Incan god. He do know quite what to make of it. Then he looks at his fingernails: they are rimmed pale bl with a clay-like substance. Hearing his mother's voice, he returns to the LIVING ROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, boys, sit with me a while.  Just hold my hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit beside her, take her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's enjoy what we have while we  have it. Reality is so fragile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in memory of Terence McKenna 1946-2000
